biography.value:
Brigganocks are frantic, mouse-sized creatures that live in mines. Whenever a mortal makes a nonmagical wish, perhaps while blowing out the candles on a birthday cake or tossing a coin down a well, an echo of that wish becomes lodged in a stone buried deep in the earth of the Feywild. Brigganocks seek out these wish stones, discarding the ones that contain wishes of ill intent and keeping those that hold good wishes. Brigganocks refine wish stones into gems and use them to decorate their architecture and crafts, or they trade them to other Fey for food and favors. A more powerful Fey creature can use a wish stone to scry on the maker of the wish, empower a supernatural charm, or provide the spark needed to create an animated object. Other uses are possible as well.

A brigganock’s soul lives outside its body, manifesting as a bulb of pale light that floats alongside it and helps the brigganock see in the dark. Brigganocks have minor spellcasting abilities that help them survive. They also have the ability to manipulate time, allowing them to accomplish hour-long tasks in a matter of seconds, though a brigganock must rest between these bursts of temporal acceleration.

Brigganocks like to nibble on cheese, lettuce, and other soft foods. They eat quite a lot for creatures of their size and never turn down a good meal.

description.value:
Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: [[/damage 1d4 + @mod type=piercing average=true]] damage.

The [[lookup @name]] attacks with its [[lookup @item.name]].

The brigganock casts one of the following spells, requiring no &Reference[material]{material} components and using &Reference[cha]{Charisma} as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 11):

At will: minor &Reference[ill]{illusion}, spare the dying

1/day each: animal friendship, faerie &Reference[fire]{fire}, meld into stone, silence

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

The brigganock accelerates the passage of time around itself, enabling it to accomplish up to 1 hour of work in a matter of seconds. This work can’t affect any creature other than the brigganock, or any object being worn or carried by another creature, and the activity must take place within a 10-foot &Reference[cube]{cube}. For example, the brigganock could use this action to rapidly carve a pumpkin, cook and eat dinner, move a pile of stones, or tie a dozen knots in a length of rope.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

monsterMunch.titleHTML: Time Lapse (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest).
monsterMunch.fullName: Time Lapse (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest).

description.value:
&Reference[fey]{Fey} Ancestry. The brigganock has advantage on saving throws against being &Reference[charmed]{charmed}, and magic can’t put it to sleep.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Soul Light. The brigganock is accompanied by an insubstantial, invulnerable ball of light that contains its soul. The brigganock can’t turn off the light or control its brightness. The soul light sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet. If the brigganock dies, its soul light fades away.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

Tunneler. Using a pickaxe or similar tool, a brigganock can burrow through solid rock at a speed of 5 feet, leaving a 6-inch-diameter tunnel in its wake.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

The brigganock moves its soul light up to 30 feet in any direction to an unoccupied space it can see. At the end of the current turn, the light returns to the brigganock.

The [[lookup @name]] uses [[lookup @item.name]].

You create a sound or an image of an object within range that lasts for the duration. The &Reference[ill]{illusion} also ends if you dismiss it as an action or cast this spell again.

If you create a sound, its volume can range from a whisper to a scream. It can be your voice, someone else's voice, a lion's roar, a beating of drums, or any other sound you choose. The sound continues unabated throughout the duration, or you can make discrete sounds at different times before the spell ends.

If you create an image of an object--such as a chair, muddy footprints, or a small chest--it must be no larger than a 5-foot &Reference[cube]{cube}. The image can't create sound, light, smell, or any other sensory effect. Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an &Reference[ill]{illusion}, because things can pass through it.

If a creature uses its action to examine the sound or image, the creature can determine that it is an &Reference[ill]{illusion} with a successful &Reference[int]{Intelligence} (&Reference[inv]{Investigation}) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the &Reference[ill]{illusion} for what it is, the &Reference[ill]{illusion} becomes faint to the creature.
You touch a living creature that has 0 hit points. The creature becomes stable. This spell has no effect on &Reference[undead]{undead} or constructs.

This spell lets you convince a &Reference[beast]{beast} that you mean it no harm. Choose a &Reference[beast]{beast} that you can see within range. It must see and hear you. If the beast's &Reference[int]{Intelligence} is 4 or higher, the spell fails. Otherwise, the &Reference[beast]{beast} must succeed on a &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} saving throw or be &Reference[charmed]{charmed} by you for the spell's duration. If you or one of your companions harms the target, the spell ends.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can affect one additional &Reference[beast]{beast} for each slot level above 1st.

Each object in a 20-foot &Reference[cube]{cube} within range is outlined in blue, green, or violet light (your choice). Any creature in the area when the spell is cast is also outlined in light if it fails a &Reference[dex]{Dexterity} saving throw. For the duration, objects and affected creatures shed dim light in a 10-foot radius.

Any attack roll against an affected creature or object has advantage if the attacker can see it, and the affected creature or object can't benefit from being &Reference[invisible]{invisible}.

You step into a stone object or surface large enough to fully contain your body, melding yourself and all the equipment you carry with the stone for the duration. Using your movement, you step into the stone at a point you can touch. Nothing of your presence remains visible or otherwise detectable by nonmagical senses.

While merged with the stone, you can't see what occurs outside it, and any &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} (&Reference[prc]{Perception}) checks you make to hear sounds outside it are made with disadvantage. You remain aware of the passage of time and can cast spells on yourself while merged in the stone. You can use your movement to leave the stone where you entered it, which ends the spell. You otherwise can't move.

Minor physical damage to the stone doesn't harm you, but its partial destruction or a change in its shape (to the extent that you no longer fit within it) expels you and deals 6d6 &Reference[bludgeoning]{bludgeoning} damage to you. The stone's complete destruction (or &Reference[trs]{transmutation} into a different substance) expels you and deals 50 &Reference[bludgeoning]{bludgeoning} damage to you. If expelled, you fall &Reference[prone]{prone} in an unoccupied space closest to where you first entered.

For the duration, no sound can be created within or pass through a 20-foot-radius &Reference[sphere]{sphere} centered on a point you choose within range. Any creature or object entirely inside the &Reference[sphere]{sphere} is immune to &Reference[thunder]{thunder} damage, and creatures are &Reference[deafened]{deafened} while entirely inside it. Casting a spell that includes a &Reference[vocal]{verbal} component is impossible there.

macro.name: Silence
